snippet: A judge nullified an important plan to increase taxi service in the outer boroughs. It is now up to the City Council to fix this problem.
abstract: Editorial urges the New York City Council to rescue important plan to increase taxi service in the outer boroughs and northern Manhattan after Judge Arthur Engoron nullified it, thereby knocking a $635 million hole in city's $68.5 billion budget.

snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday's selection includes an analysis of how a cellphone screen shatters, an algorithm that can identify a city's architectural style and ...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday's selection includes an analysis of how a cellphone screen shatters, an algorithm that can identify a city's architectural style and a theory that encouraging companies to imitate each other would promote innovation.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Smashing Screens and Competitive Copying

snippet: AT&T will only allow iPhone users to place FaceTime video calls on a shared data plan, which has raised debate on whether the carrier is violating government net neutrality rules.
abstract: AT&T will only allow iPhone users to place FaceTime video calls on a shared data plan, which has raised debate on whether the carrier is violating government net neutrality rules.

headline.main: AT&T's FaceTime Restrictions Could Be Violating F.C.C. Rules

snippet: On Monday Apple became the most highly valued public company ever, but Microsoft still holds the record when its 1999 value is adjusted for inflation.
abstract: On Monday Apple became the most highly valued public company ever, but Microsoft still holds the record when its 1999 value is adjusted for inflation.

headline.main: Apple Becomes the Most Valuable Public Company Ever, With an Asterisk
headline.print_headline: Apple Sets Stock Market Record, With Asterisk

snippet: With many traders and investors on vacation, just 2.7 billion shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange, where the 2012 average has been one billion more.
abstract: Stocks slip on one of the quietest trading sessions of the year, as worries about European debt return.

headline.main: Shares Waver as Worry Rises on European Debt
headline.print_headline: Shares Waver as Worry Rises on European Debt

snippet: The Apple-Samsung patent trial is expected to wind down this week, and legal experts say a victory for either company could have broad implications for makers of smartphones and tablet computers, Nick Wingfield reports in Monday's New York Times.
abstract: The Apple-Samsung patent trial is expected to wind down this week, and legal experts say a victory for either company could have broad implications for makers of smartphones and tablet computers, Nick Wingfield reports in Monday's New York Times.

headline.main: Daily Report: Apple-Samsung Decision Could Have Wide Impact

snippet: The nation's leading bookstore chain said it would announce partnerships with "leading retailers" in Britain at a later time.
abstract: The nation's leading bookstore chain said it would announce partnerships with "leading retailers" in Britain at a later time.

headline.main: Barnes & Noble to Offer the Nook in Britain
headline.print_headline: Barnes & Noble Is to Sell Its E-Reader in Britain

snippet: In Apple's iOS software, you can choose which apps you want to see in your Notification Center and the style of the alert messages themselves.
abstract: In Apple's iOS software, you can choose which apps you want to see in your Notification Center and the style of the alert messages themselves.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Customizing iOS Notifications

snippet: The problem when companies go to trial is that the public gets to hear corporate secrets.
abstract: Chart features corporate secrets learned by the public in the Apple-Samsung patent trial.

snippet: Under pressure to expand, media companies are capitalizing on the changes that technology is bringing to classrooms.
abstract: Media companies are introducing digital textbooks, capitalizing on changes that technology is bringing to classrooms; sales for conventional textbooks for kindergarten through 12th grade are reportedly $3 billion, with additional $4 billion for teacher guides and other reference materials; educators say almost all printed material will eventually be replaced by digital versions.

headline.main: Media Companies, Seeing Profit Slip, Push Into Education
headline.print_headline: The Classroom as a Cash Cow

byline.original: By BROOKS BARNES and AMY CHOZICK
